Question: Translate the subordinate clause in the following sentence into English: “Sī omnēs bene dormiunt, nēmō iam est fessus,”
Bonus 1: Translate the subordinate clause in the following sentence into English: “Cum rēgēs in terrīs vīvēbant, hominēs beātī erant,”
Bonus 2: Translate the subordinate clause in the following sentence into English: “Numāsius quī amīcus Maniō fuit fibulam auream recēpit,”
Bonus 2 Answer: WHO WAS A FRIEND TO MANIUS

Question: Phobos and Deimos drove the chariot of what Greek deity, who was trapped in a net and mocked by the gods when he was caught in bed with Aphrodite
Bonus 1: Which Olympian finally convinced Hephaestus to release Ares and Aphrodite from the net
Bonus 2: What two giant brothers captured Ares and stuffed him in a bronze jar for thirteen months

Question: After a series of reforms including an ill-fated Edict on Maximum Prices, what emperor made the unprecedented decision to abdicate in 305 A.D. confident that he had ensured a stable succession by establishing the tetrarchy
Bonus 1: What son of his co-ruler Maximian, angry at not succeeding his biological father, took power until his defeat at Milvian Bridge
Bonus 2: The last vestiges of Diocletian’s influence ended when what Eastern Augustus, having succeeded Diocletian to the position, issued a deathbed Edict of Toleration ending the Christian persecutions Diocletian had started

Question: Which of the following words, if any, is not derived from the same Latin root as the others: enunciate, denounce, annunciation, pronoun?
Bonus 1: From what noun with what meaning are all the others derived?
Bonus 2: From what noun with what meaning is “pronoun” derived?

Question: What Trojan priest of Thymbraean Apollo hurled a spear at the Trojan Horse as a warning before two serpents killed him and his two sons?
Bonus 1: What Greek spy allowed himself to be captured by the Trojans in order to convince them to accept the wooden horse as a gift?
Bonus 2: The episode with Sinon can be compared to the episode with Achaemenides, a member of Odysseus’ crew, who was accidentally abandoned when the Greeks fled from what island, home to Polyphemus?

Question: From what Latin verb with what meaning are the English words “adroit,” “incorrigible,” and “regiment” derived?
Bonus 1: From what Latin verb with what meaning is “surrogate” derived?
Bonus 2: From what Latin verb with what meaning is “risible” derived?

Question: What woman speaks the following lines in Sophocles’s "Trachinian Women"? “When I smeared the ointment on my husband’s robe, [...] I followed to the letter everything that beastly centaur told me, as he lay with the death-bearing arrow in his side.”
Bonus 1: To whom does Heracles speak the following lines in a Sophocles play? “Stay, son of Poeas, until you’ve heard me. [...] Go to Troy with this man to be healed , to be first for your power and with my bow to topple Paris, seed of all your suffering.”
Bonus 2: Identify the speaker of the following lines from Aeschylus: “No, keep quiet and keep yourself clear of harm. For even if I am in a sore plight, I would not wish affliction on everyone else. No, certainly, no! since, besides, I am distressed by the fate of my brother Atlas, who, towards the west, stands bearing on his shoulders the pillar of heaven and earth, a burden not easy for his arms to grasp.”

Question: From what Latin verb with what meaning are the English words “adroit,” “incorrigible,” and “regiment” derived,?
Bonus 1: From what Latin verb with what meaning is “surrogate” derived,?
Bonus 2: From what Latin verb with what meaning is “risible” derived,?

Question: Identify the use of the accusative in the following Latin sentence: "Quattuor hōrās stetimus in mediā viā."
Answer: DURATION / EXTENT OF TIME // TIME HOW LONG
Bonus 1: Identify the use of the genitive in the following Latin sentence: "Cēnam ēdī dē pōculō pānis."
Bonus 2: Identify both uses of the ablative in the following Latin sentence: "Multō maior sum sorōre meā."
Bonus 2 Answer: COMPARATIVE / COMPARISON and DEGREE OF DIFFERENCE

Question: Translate the subordinate clause in the following sentence into English, 'Sī omnēs bene dormiunt nēmō iam est fessus.'
Answer: IF EVERYONE SLEEPS WELL // IF ALL SLEEP WELL
Bonus 1: Translate the subordinate clause in the following sentence into English, 'Cum rēgēs in terrīs vīvēbant hominēs beātī erant.'
Bonus 1 Answer: WHEN KINGS LIVED / WERE LIVING IN LANDS / ON THE EARTH
Bonus 2: Translate the subordinate clause in the following sentence into English, 'Numāsius quī amīcus Maniō fuit fibulam auream recēpit.'
Bonus 2 Answer: WHO WAS FRIENDLY TO MANIUS // WHO WAS A FRIEND TO/OF MANIUS

Question: What fisherman, whose name literally means “net,” found a washed-up chest on the shores of Seriphos, saving Danaë and Perseus?
Bonus 1: What brother of Dictys was the king of Seriphos and demanded Danaë’s hand in marriage?
Bonus 2: According to Hyginus, Polydectes married Danaë and helped her son Perseus reconcile with what man, his grandfather and the father of Danaë?

Question: What general of the late Republic began his career by raising three legions in Picenum to support Sulla, was given extraordinary commissions to rid the Mediterranean of pirates and to finish off the Third Mithridatic War, and formed the First Triumvirate with Caesar and Crassus?
Bonus 1: What general had made significant progress in the Third Mithridatic War before the lēx Mānīlia replaced him with Pompey?
Bonus 2: When Pompey returned from his Eastern expeditions in 62 B.C.C he was chagrined to find that the Senate was more interested in praising the domestic achievements of what consul of 63 B.C.?

Question: Translate the motto of Kansas, ‘ad astra per aspera,’
Bonus 1: Translate the motto of Virginia
Bonus 2: Translate the motto of Oregon
Bonus 2 Answer: SHE / HE FLIES ON / WITH HER / HIS OWN WINGS

Question: Poseidon gave a golden chariot drawn by winged steeds to what man, who used it to defeat a king of Pisa, Oenomaus, in a race where he won the hand of Hippodameia?
Bonus 1: Pelops defeated Oenomaus with the help of what treacherous charioteer, who removed the linchpins from the wheels of Oenomaus's chariot?
Bonus 2: When Pelops then betrayed the treacherous Myrtilus, the former charioteer laid a curse on Pelops and his descendants which manifested in which feuding sons of Pelops?
